before_start: {"blocks":[{"key":"7ad1","text":"Ensure ample table space is available, and located in a well ventilated area. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3rqed","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"2vi9n","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"safety","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6o1db","text":"● Wear eyewear protection at all times","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6i0e","text":"● Wear gloves and lab coat at all times ","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}
description: {"blocks":[{"key":"2onmg","text":"Laser inscribed graphene (LIG) is a versatile material that is commonly used to prepare electrochemical sensors (Moreira et al 2023). This protocol describes the fabrication of a 3-electrode plug-and-play chip system based on LIG. The design is compatible with a female USB-A connector which can be modified for connection to any potentiostat using the protocol here. The complete process requires approximately 60 min to complete, including fabrication of USB-A connector (Fig 1). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":474,"length":5}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7qo6b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cfj5a","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"78cm7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"height":415,"id":455050,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"2qu9o\",\"text\":\"Figure 1. Process flow for fabrication of laser inscribed graphene (LIG) chip compatible with USB-A. The process shown here is for a batch of 18 LIG chips, and requires approximately 60 min to complete. The USB-A adapter may be reused, and thus is shown as a separate section. The protocol depends on referenced protocols for fabrication of LIG (not shown here).\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":8}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","originalFile":{},"original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/p6nnbnd3x.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/p6nkbnd3x.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/p6nmbnd3x.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/p6njbnd3x.webp","width":550}}}}

keywords: Laser inscribed graphene, LIG, electrode, chip, plug-and-play

status.info: We use this protocol and it's working

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"71vai","text":"Step 1) Fabrication of USB-A Adapter ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":37}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dpjaa","text":"Heat the soldering iron, and prepare a wet sponge and solder wick. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4uthf","text":"See the following for an introduction to soldering techniques (link)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":63,"length":4}],"data":{}},{"key":"dv0ee","text":"Solder one 28AWG jumper wire to each of the two outer contacts in the USB-A adapter. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cf2re","text":"Create an electrical connection (i.e., “jump”) the two inner contacts in the USB-A adapter.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e4ri5","text":"Solder one 28AWG jumper wire to the “jumped” inner contact(s) in the USB-A adapter","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5h2ot","text":"Place the plastic cover on the USB-A Female adapter","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5jiaq","text":"Turn off soldering iron, and clean station when\nfinished","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"91F1643EEA0911EEB9010A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://learn.adafruit.com/adafruit-guide-excellent-soldering?gad_source=1\u0026gclid=CjwKCAjwnv-vBhBdEiwABCYQA9wa5V9qMLihFGSDF1GE6j580yBSFybVTeHXOjTLpgD59oByVPmlkhoCLHYQAvD_BwE"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"5tuec","text":"Step 2) Preparation of Materials for LIG chip","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":45}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"36kbn","text":"LIG should be prepared using the protocol developed for a 3-electrode sensor (link)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":78,"length":4}],"data":{}},{"key":"9sf6h","text":"Using scissors, cut conductive polyester metal tape into 0.3 cm by 3.5 cm strips (one strip per LIG electrode)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"durij","text":"Fig. 1 shows an example of a batch of 18 LIG electrodes with 18 metal tape strips","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"64d26","text":"For each LIG chip, cut a 1cm by 5 cm strip of PVC to act as the chip base ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cfv4q","text":"Ample table space should be cleared to prepare the LIG chips ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7kl9t","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"blmnu","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"4ebo1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"agu0l","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"46kll","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"bujo","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"16B4B563EA0A11EEB9010A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.protocols.io/view/lig-fabrication-universal-laser-system-cigkubuw"}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":13,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"7ua6s","text":"Critical Step: ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"bgqnd","text":"Ensure that the PVC base is the correct width by inserting into the USB-A female adapter. The fit should not be too loose, but should be snug when inserted.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"2":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"height":429,"id":455054,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"2tip8\",\"text\":\"Figure 1.  Photo of materials prepared for a batch of 18 LIG electrodes with 18 polyester metal tape strips (PVC base strips not shown in photo)\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":10}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","originalFile":{},"original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/p6nsbnd3x.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/p6nqbnd3x.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/p6nrbnd3x.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/p6npbnd3x.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"cbjrf","text":"Step 3) Adhesion of Bonding Pads to LIG","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":39}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2p1op","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"733am","text":"Using scissors, cut small 0.3 cm by 1.0 cm strips from the prepared
polyester metal tape strips. One small subsection should be cut for each 3-electrode
LIG sensor.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eocjh","text":"Using steel tweezers, hold the metal tape and carefully remove the adhesive
backing","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"amujn","text":"Carefully position the metal tape over one of the bonding pads on the printed
LIG chip","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1guvu","text":"After coating the LIG reference electrode, the
tweezers should be used to lightly squeeze the material and ensure good
contact.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"85jk6","text":"Repeat the process for all three electrodes in the LIG chip (Fig 2)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":61,"length":5}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bpv9o","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9uavl","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9epjq","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"6r81j","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ae4iu","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"dp8r8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":14,"offset":0,"style":"bold"},{"length":13,"offset":0,"style":"UNDERLINE"}],"key":"7f1m","text":"Critical step:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"d0qp4","text":"Use caution and avoid touching the surface of the LIG material ","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"1":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"height":340,"id":455058,"is_video":false,"legend":"{"blocks":[{"key":"dnlk2","text":"Figure 2. Photo demonstrating adhesion of polyester metal tape strips to bonding pad of\nLIG design. Each bonding pad corresponds to the working, counter, or reference electrode.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}","mime":"image/png","originalFile":{},"original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/p6nwbnd3x.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/p6nubnd3x.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/p6nvbnd3x.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/p6ntbnd3x.webp","width":550}},"2":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":14,"offset":0,"style":"bold"},{"length":13,"offset":0,"style":"UNDERLINE"}],"key":"bdljq","text":"Critical step:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"3l3ib","text":"Care must be taken to ensure that the metal tape used to create bonding pads is not contacting other components of the chip, including other bonding pads.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"591vq","text":"Step 4) Coating of LIG Reference Electrode","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":42}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4mpvv","text":"The reference electrode may be coated with Ag/AgCl ink, or with a small 0.3 cm by 0.5 cm strip of polyester metal tape (as shown here)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cg2bs","text":"After coating the LIG reference electrode, the tweezers should be used to lightly squeeze the material and ensure good contact. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aqepu","text":"If Ag/AgCl ink is used to coat the reference electrode, the material should be allowed to cure at room temperature for at least 15 min","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"83oek","text":"Step 5) Passivation of LIG Electrodes","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":37}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2mfjg","text":"Use poly gel acrylic nail polish to passivate the electrodes between the bonding pad and the functional electrode area (Fig 3A).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":120,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"m1fd","text":"The passivation may cover a small portion of the polyester metal tape if used as reference electrode coating material (Fig 3B)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":119,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5hc30","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"fo441","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"height":235,"id":455062,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"c6dof\",\"text\":\"Figure 3. Passivation of LIG electrodes for creating functional electrode area and bonding pads.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":10}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","originalFile":{},"original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/p6n2bnd3x.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/p6nybnd3x.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/p6nzbnd3x.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/p6nxbnd3x.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7ojks","text":"Step 6) Mounting LIG chip to PVC Base","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":37}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4drd","text":"Using scissors, cut a strip of double sided tape and adhere to the back of the LIG material (Fig 4A).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":93,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bdhds","text":"Mount the LIG material to the PVC base and use scissors to trim any excess tape.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b5853","text":"The final chip should have clearance with exposed, unmodified PVC which may be handled without touching the LIG or other coating materials (Fig 4B)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":140,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4k1va","text":"The three electrode system is composed of working, counter, and reference electrodes. The passivation area and bonding pad are easily discernable (Fig 4C)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":147,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cnt9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c2o2b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"brkh1","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"64bfs","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"height":171,"id":455066,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"cs6a0\",\"text\":\"Figure 4. A) Cut a strip of double sided tape and adhere to back of LIG. B) LIG electrode mounted to PVC base. C) Example of completed LIG chip for plug-and-play with USB-A system. C) The final design is a plug-and-play 3 electrode LIG chip compatible with the USB-A adapter\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":12},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":73,\"length\":2},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":181,\"length\":3}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","originalFile":{},"original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/p6n6bnd3x.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/p6n4bnd3x.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/p6n5bnd3x.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/p6n3bnd3x.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"1ph36","text":"Step 7) Clean up laboratory","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":27}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5lo7n","text":"Any excess polyamide, metal tape, or PVC sheet should be discarded in a labeled container on the counter.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"nbbf","text":"Turn off soldering iron, and clean station","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"20fiv","text":"If storing electrodes, place in a sealed Petri dish with desiccant.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

Proper use of PPE should avoid any problems (link
to health hazard
